This case, sadly, was terminal, but the post-mortem metabolic investigation yielded the definitive answer, teaching us a profound lesson in adult presentation of genetic disease. DIAGNOSIS: Adult-Onset Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) Deficiency THE SMOKING GUN: The key metabolic pathway intermediate that confirmed the diagnosis was found during specialized plasma and urine analysis: Severe Orotic Aciduria (Elevated Urine Orotate levels) PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: OTC Deficiency is the most common Urea Cycle Disorder (UCD), an X-linked metabolic condition. In affected individuals, the OTC enzyme (located in the liver mitochondria) is unable to catalyze the second step of the urea cycle, converting carbamoyl phosphate (CP) and ornithine into citrulline. 1. Ammonia Toxicity: The failure to incorporate ammonia into the urea cycle results in massive systemic hyperammonemia (as seen in J.R.). Ammonia is highly neurotoxic, causing astrocyte swelling and ultimately severe cerebral edema (the cause of death). 2. The Orotate Shunt: When OTC is blocked, the precursor, carbamoyl phosphate, accumulates. This excess CP is shunted out of the mitochondria into the cytoplasm, where it enters the pyrimidine synthesis pathway. Orotic acid is an intermediate in this pathway. 3. Adult Presentation: Although typically catastrophic in neonates, milder, X-linked cases (often partial enzyme activity) can present acutely in adulthood, usually triggered by a catabolic stressor (like the preceding viral illness, prolonged high-protein diet, or severe caloric restriction) that rapidly mobilizes endogenous protein, overwhelming the already deficient urea cycle capacity.
